data.title: Olivier Awards: how a tiny theatre in north London trounced the West End
data.meta_description: Islington's Almeida Theatre was the big winner at the Olivier Theatre awards on Sunday night
data.text:
It may describe itself as a “small room” and “local theatre”, but the Almeida proved itself anything but a theatrical minnow as it took home a remarkable eight awards at the Oliviers on Sunday night - a third of the total.

The theatre, based in Islington and seating just 325 people, was home to Chimerica, which won five awards including best new play and best director, and Ghosts, which won three.

Actors hailed the small venue as being the “best way to do theatre”, as director Sir Richard Eyre said the experience was an “emancipation” after the pressure of the West End.

His play, Ghosts, won best revival as its star Lesley Manville beat Dame Judi Dench to win her first best actress award.

Manville triumphed over veteran Dame Judi, who has won seven Olivier Awards in her career as well as picking up Bafta, Oscar and Golden Globe nominations this year.

“Where have you been all my life?” she asked as she picked up her first Olivier. “I’m so happy, I’m fizzing with delight.”

Writing ahead of the announcement yesterday, he said the theatres of Shaftesbury Avenue were “heavily indebted” to the smaller houses, “where risk-taking and excellence are the watchwords.”

It is the first Olivier awards for the Almeida since 2006, when it won four for Hedda Gabler. The theatre is now run by artistic director Rupert Goold, following 11 years with Michael Attenborough at the helm.

Best Actor Rory Kinnear and Best Actress Lesley Manville (PA)

At the National Theatre, which in contrast houses more than 1,000 ticket-holders in its Olivier theatre, Rory Kinnear took home the award for best actor for his role in Othello.

It is his first Olivier for best actor, after winning best supporting performance in 2008 for The Man Of Mode.

Lesley Manville took home her first best actress Olivier for her starring role in Ibsen’s Ghosts, which has since transferred to Trafalgar Studios, pipping Anna Chancellor for Private Lives, Hayley Atwell for The Pride and Dame Judi Dench.

Dame Judi, who was nominated for her appearance in Peter and Alice at the Noel Coward Theatre, missed out on what has been considered her final chance for a major award this season, after also being nominated for a Bafta, Golden Globe and Oscar for her film Philomena.

In a ceremony at the Royal Opera House, hosted by Stephen Mangan and Gemma Arterton, the industry hailed the Almeida Theatre and Chimerica as the “big winners” of the night.

Mangan himself also picked up an award, as Jeeves & Wooster In Perfect Nonsense won best new comedy.

The cast of 'The Book Of Mormon' (GETTY)

The Book of Mormon, which opened in London last year to critical and popular acclaim, dominated the musical categories, taking home four awards including best new musical and best actor in a musical for Gavin Creel.

The National Theatre was also recognised, with Sir Nick Hytner and Nick Starr, the artistic and executive directors, receiving a Special Award for outstanding achievement. It will be their last year working in partnership at the National before moving on to a new joint pursuit, with Rufus Norris set to take the helm.

Jack Lowden: Best Actor in a Supporting Role (PA)

Ghosts, directed by Sir Richard Eyre, won three awards in total, with Manville’s best actress matched by Jack Lowden for best supporting actor and the award for best revival.

Sir Richard missed out on the best director award, which went to Lyndsey Turner for Chimerica.

Following the award for best revival, the first of the evening, he said the experience of working out of the West End had been “emancipating”.

“You’re not panicking about what you can fill the theatre every night, there’s none of the hysterical pressure as when there’s an awful lot of cash and reputations hanging on it,” he said. “It’s relaxed, and people produce their best work when they’re relaxed.”

Manville and Lowden both praised the intimacy of a small theatre, with the proximity actors to their audience making it the “best way to do theatre”.

Merrily We Roll Along, at the Harold Pinter Theatre, won best musical revival while the long-running Les Miserables took home the Radio 2 Audience Award.

Nigel Planer, Special Award winner Michael White and Kate Moss (GETTY)

Michael White was presented with a special award for his long career in the industry, unexpectedly handed to him by his “good friend”, the supermodel Kate Moss.

The show, broadcast on ITV, also saw the reunion of ABBA’s Benny Andersson and Bjorn Ulvaeus, for a performance to celebrate 15 years of Mamma Mia! on the stage.

The 2014 Olivier Awards were held tonight. Here is a full list of winners:

:: Best Actor - Rory Kinnear for Othello at the National Theatre

:: Best Actress - Lesley Manville for Ghosts at the Almeida Theatre and Trafalgar Studios

:: Best Actor in a Supporting Role - Jack Lowden for Ghosts at the Almeida Theatre and Trafalgar Studios

:: Best Actress in a Supporting Role - Sharon D Clarke for The Amen Corner at the National Theatre

:: American Airlines Best New Play - Chimerica at the Almeida Theatre and Harold Pinter Theatre

:: Best New Comedy - Jeeves and Wooster In Perfect Nonsense at the Duke of York's Theatre

:: Best Director - Lyndsey Turner for Chimerica at the Almeida Theatre and Harold Pinter Theatre

:: Best Actor in a Musical - Gavin Creel for The Book Of Mormon at the Prince of Wales Theatre

:: Best Actress in a Musical - Zrinka Cvitesic for Once at the Phoenix Theatre

:: Best Performance in a Supporting Role in a Musical - Stephen Ashfield for The Book Of Mormon at the Prince of Wales Theatre

:: MasterCard Best New Musical - The Book Of Mormon at the Prince of Wales Theatre

:: Best Revival - Ghosts at the Almeida Theatre and Trafalgar Studios

:: Best Musical Revival - Merrily We Roll Along at the Harold Pinter Theatre

:: Best Theatre Choreographer - Casey Nicholaw for The Book Of Mormon at the Prince of Wales Theatre

:: Best Entertainment and Family - The Wind In The Willows at the Duchess Theatre

:: Autograph Sound Award for Outstanding Achievement in Music - Once - Martin Lowe for composition and arrangements, Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova for music and lyrics

:: White Light Award for Best Lighting Design - Tim Lutkin and Finn Ross for Chimerica at the Almeida Theatre and Harold Pinter Theatre and Paul Pyant and Jon Driscoll for Charlie And The Chocolate Factory at Theatre Royal Drury Lane

:: Best Sound Design - Carolyn Downing for Chimerica at the Almeida Theatre and Harold Pinter Theatre and Gareth Owen for Merrily We Roll Along at the Harold Pinter Theatre

:: XL Video Award for Best Set Design - Es Devlin for Chimerica at the Almeida Theatre and Harold Pinter Theatre

:: Outstanding Achievement in an Affiliate Theatre - Handbagged at the Tricycle Theatre

:: Best New Dance Production - Eastman - Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui & Sadler's Wells for Puz/zle at Sadler's Wells

:: Outstanding Achievement in Dance - Michael Hulls for his body of lighting work including Ballet Boyz - The Talent at Sadler's Wells

:: Best New Opera Production - Les Vepres Siciliennes at the Royal Opera House

:: Outstanding Achievement in Opera - English Touring Opera for its brave and challenging touring productions at the Linbury Studio Theatre, Royal Opera House

:: BBC Radio 2 Audience Award - Les Miserables at the Queen's Theatre

:: Special Award - impresario Michael White
